children.name: have nothing on b1
children.definition: have nothing on/ not have anything on especiallyspokento not be wearing any clothes:không mặc đồ
examples: don’t come in yet - i don’t have anything on!
i didn’t want to walk near the windows with nothing on.

children.name: naked b2
children.definition: naked wearing no clothes - used especially when this seems rather shocking: trần truồng
examples: he was lying on the bed, completely naked.
the magazine was full of pictures of naked men.
the children ran naked through the yard.
a picture of a naked man
they found the body lyinghalf nakedin the grass.
the governor ordered the prisoner to bestripped nakedand whipped.
starknaked/bucknakeduscompletelynaked:lõa thể
i walked in, and mr tolifero was standing there buck naked.
register
in everyday english, people often say that someonehas nothing onordoesn’t have anything onrather than say theyare naked:
they ran through the yardwith nothing on.

children.name: undressed b2
children.definition: undressed not wearing any clothes, especially because you have just taken them off in order to go to bed, have a bath etc :không mặc đồ
examples: when you’re undressed, the nurse will come back and explain the procedure.
sara was undressed and ready for bed but jenny was fully clothed.

children.name: bare b2
children.definition: bare apartof your body that is bare is not covered by any clothes:trần
examples: a ragged child with bare feet
the dress tied around her neck, leaving her shoulders bare.
the sand was too hot to walk on in bare feet.
don't walk around outsideinyour barefeet.
she felt the warm sun on her bare arms.
bare-headed/ bare-chested/bare-legged etc
some of the men wear hats, others are bareheaded
bareheaded cycling makes the world a riskier place
barefoot[adj] [adv] not wearing any shoes or socks :chân không; chân trần
we took off our shoes and socks andwalkedbarefoot along the beach.

children.name: nude x
children.definition: nude a word meaningnaked, used especially when talking aboutimagesof naked people in paintings, films etc:khỏa thân
examples: at the front of the painting is a nude figure carrying a torch.
nude photograph/scene/drawing etcshowing someone wearing no clothes:
on the wall was a nude drawing of her husband.
a nude portrait of his wife
nudity[u]
attitudes to nudity in films have changed in recent years.
nudist/ naturist[c] sb who enjoys not wearing any clothes because they believe it is natural and healthy : người theo chủ nghĩa khỏa thân
a close friend who is a nudist, convinced michelle to visit the community with him.
nudist/naturist[adjective]
there are naturist beaches on most of the greek islands.
nudism/naturism[u]

children.name: in the nude x
children.definition: in the nude if you do sth in the nude, you do it wearing no clothes at all, especially when this is unusual, exciting, or shocking:đang khỏa thân
examples: he told me he cleans his house in the nude!
the pictures show collier on top of a new york skyscraper in the nude.
men and women swam together in the nude and thought nothing of it.

children.name: in your birthday suit x
children.definition: in your birthday suitinformalwithout any clothes on - usedhumorously:
examples: martin’s threatened to turn up for the wedding in his birthday suit.
he likes to sleep in his birthday suit. he says pyjamas are uncomfortable.

children.name: in the buff x
children.definition: in the buff informalnot wearing any clothes - a very informal use :
examples: a beach where you can sunbathe in the buff

children.name: go commando x
children.definition: go commandoinformal humorousto not wear any underwear :
examples: in summertime, he likes to go commando.

children.name: topless x
children.definition: topless describes sb, usually a woman, wearing nothing on the upper part of their body, or something connected with this way of dressing: :
examples: a topless waitress
topless dancers/ bars/ sunbathing
go topless
many women now go topless on the beach.

children.name: wear a1
children.definition: wear to have clothes, shoes, glasses, jewellery etc on your body :mặc, vận ,mang, đeo, đội, xỏ, khoác
examples: she was wearing shorts and a t-shirt.
were you wearing your jacket when we got on the bus?
wear black/red/green etcwear black clothes, red clothes etc
carolyn always wore bright colors like red.
sb wears sthsbusuallywears a particular type of clothes
she wears sandals, even in the winter.
i wear a lot of black.

children.name: in b1
children.definition: in
examples: in a suit/in a red dress etcwearing a suit, a red dress etc: mặc đồ gì
a couple of boys in baseball caps
there was a man in a linen suit standing at the bar.

children.name: have on b1
children.definition: have on to be wearing clothes, shoes, glasses, or jewellery.have sth onis more informal thanwear: mặc
examples: have a coat/jacket/suit etc on
that’s jenny salton over there; she has a blue dress on. jenny slalton
could you read this for me? i don’t have my glasses on.
have on a coat/jacket/suit etc
‘what was she wearing?’ ‘i think she had on a dark suit.’"
i loved that dress you had on last night.

children.name: be bundled up x
children.definition: be bundled up to be wearing alot ofwarmclothes because it is cold:mặc đồ ấm
examples: be bundled up in
the old man sat on his porch bundled up in old sweaters and scarves.
be bundled up against the cold/rain/wind etc
spectators, bundled up against the cold, stood and listened to the president speak for an hour.

children.name: be kitted out in x
children.definition: be kitted out in uk to be wearing aparticularkind of clothes, especially todo an activity:
examples: mặc đồ gì (cho một hoạt động nào đó)
anna was kitted out in her riding gear, waiting by the car.

children.name: to wear clothes in a particular way
dressed b1
children.definition: dressed wearing a particular type of clothes :
examples: well-dressed(= wearing nice clothes of good quality )the restaurant was full of well-dressed couples.
smartly/elegantly/beautifully/neatly etc dressedthere was a smartly dressed man with a briefcase at the door.
fashionably dressed(= wearing clothes that are fashionable)most teenagers want to be fashionably dressed.
immaculately/impeccably dressed(= perfectly dressed in smart clothes)he was immaculately dressed in a grey suit and a blue tie.
casually dressed(= wearing informal clothes )luke was casually dressed in jeans and a white shirt.
properly/suitably dressed(= wearing suitable clothes for something )it’s important to be properly dressed if you are walking in the mountains.
badly dressed(= not well dressed )the prime minister’s been criticized for being badly dressed.
shabbily/scruffily dressed(= wearing clothes that are old and untidy )a dirty, shabbily dressed man was sitting on the bench.
dressed to killintentionally wearing clothes that attract sexual attention and admiration
hopefully all the fashionable people from the sheffield scene will be there and be dressed to kill.
dressed (up) to the ninesinformal to be wearing fashionable or formal clothes for a special occasion
jackie went out dressed to the nines.

children.name: dresser x
children.definition: dresserused in phrases which describe the type of clothes that someone wears
examples: a fashionable/ stylish/ sloppy etc dresser
stanley was an impeccable dresser.
she was always a very stylish dresser.
he's a verysnappy(= stylish and modern) dresser.

children.name: dress sense x
children.definition: dress sense the ability to dress well in attractivecombinations of clothes that suit you:khiếu ăn mặc
examples: have dress sense/ have no dress sense

children.name: overdressed x
children.definition: overdressed dressed in clothes that are too formal for the occasion :ăn mặc quá diện
examples: everyone else was wearing jeans so i felt a bit overdressed in my best suit.

children.name: underdressed x
children.definition: underdressed wearing clothes that are too informal for a particular occasion :ăn mặc xuềnh xoàng,ăn mặc quá sơ sài
examples: everyone else was in smart suits and i felt a bit underdressed.

children.name: power dressing x
children.definition: power dressing when you wear a particular style of clothes in order to emphasize how important or powerful you are, especially at work :ăn mặc thể hiện cá tính và quyền lự
examples: thomas was amazed at the `power dressing' at airports.
however, he feels the concept of power dressing among women will take some time.
i'm talking power dressing at whole new level.

children.name: to wear sth more formal or informal
be dressed up x
children.definition: be dressed up us to be wearingformalclothes or yourbestclothes, for example on aspecialoccasion:ăn diện
examples: look at you - you’re all dressed up!
harvey arrived, dressed up in his only business suit.

children.name: dress down x
children.definition: dress down uk to wear clothes that are moreinformalthan you usually wear:mặc đồ bình thường (hơn so với mọi ngày)
examples: we dress down at work these days, unless we’re going to a client meeting.

children.name: dressed a2
children.definition: dressed having your clothes on: có mặc đồ
examples: aren’t you dressed yet?
are you dressed yet? we have to leave now!
fully dressed(=with all your clothes on)she was so tired that she went to bed fully dressed.
she lay down fully dressed on the bed.
half dressed(=not having finished putting your clothes on)don’t come in – i’m only half dressed!
be dressed inespecially writtento be wearing clothes, used especially in written descriptions when describing the clothes that someone is wearing: có mặc đồ
they were all dressed in t-shirts and jeans.
a woman dressed in green
alistair was dressed in his best suit and tie.
be dressed as sbwearing clothes that make you look like someone else:
some of the children were dressed as soldiers.

children.name: clothed x
children.definition: clothedformalwearing clothes :
examples: be clothed in sth
the king was clothed in a purple gown.
fully/partially/scantily etc clothed
the children lay on the bed, fully clothed and fast asleep.

children.name: decent x
children.definition: decent informal wearing enough clothes so that you do not show too much of your body – used humorously : “lịch sự, tử tế”
examples: are you decent yet?
you can come in now, i'm decent.
are you decent? can i come in?

children.name: dress code x
children.definition: dress code a set of rules for what you can wear :quy định về trang phục
examples: my school had a very strict dress code.
most evenings there's a party and the dress code is strict - black tie only.

children.name: wearer x
children.definition: wearer the person wearing sth :người mang; người đeo; người mặc; người đội
examples: in medieval times the sapphire was believed to offer protection to its wearer.
clothes, of course, say a lot about the wearer.
bicycle helmets offer wearers protection against head injury.
hearing aid wearers

children.name: clothe x
children.definition: clothe to provide sb with clothes: cho mặc
examples: it costs a lot to feed and clothe five children.
they could barely keep the family fed and clothed.
